description: Probably of North Germanic origin, from or cognate with Old Norse skran (“rubbish; marine stores”). Compare Icelandic skran (“junk”), Danish skrammel (“junk, lumber”). Doublet of scrawn.

entries.meaning: (UK, Ireland, slang) Food, especially that of an inferior quality; grub.
examples: Let wi gan and get some scran am starvin man!Let's go and get some food. I'm starving!

verbs.description: scran (third-person singular simple present scrans, present participle scranning, simple past and past participle scranned)
